title: Psalms Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:1, who is being asked about dwelling in the LORD's tabernacle?
options: Who shall abide in thy tabernacle?
Who shall worship in the temple?
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall abide in thy tabernacle?
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:1 asks, 'LORD, who shall abide in thy tabernacle?' which means who is worthy to dwell there.

questions.question: What kind of person does Psalms 15:2 describe as dwelling on the holy hill?
options: He that walketh uprightly, and worketh righteousness, and speaketh the truth in his heart.
He that is wealthy and powerful.
questions.correctAnswer: He that walketh uprightly, and worketh righteousness, and speaketh the truth in his heart.
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 states that the one who dwells on the holy hill walks uprightly, works righteousness, and speaks truth in their heart.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:3, which of these actions disqualifies a person from dwelling with God?
questions.correctAnswer: Backbiting with the tongue
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 highlights that one who does not backbite with the tongue nor do evil to a neighbour is fit to dwell with God.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 15:4 says a person who honours those who fear the LORD is one who can dwell in God's presence.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 states the one who honours those that fear the LORD is among those who shall abide with God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 15:5: 'He that putteth not out his money to ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: usury
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 says, 'He that putteth not out his money to usury,' meaning he does not lend money at interest.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:4, what does the righteous person do when swearing to his own hurt?
questions.correctAnswer: He changeth not
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 states that the person who swears to his own hurt and does not change is righteous.

questions.question: Who is described as being contemned in the eyes of the righteous person in Psalms 15:4?
questions.correctAnswer: A vile person
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 says, 'In whose eyes a vile person is contemned;' meaning the righteous despises the vile.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 15:3 teaches that one should take up reproach against their neighbour.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 explicitly states the righteous do not take up a reproach against their neighbour.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:5, which of the following is NOT a characteristic of the person who will never be moved?
options: Does not lend money at usury
questions.correctAnswer: Takes reward against the innocent
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 says the person who takes no reward against the innocent will never be moved, implying taking reward against the innocent is wrong.

questions.question: What question is asked at the beginning of Psalms 15:1?
options: Who shall abide in thy tabernacle?
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall abide in thy tabernacle?
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:1 opens with the question, 'LORD, who shall abide in thy tabernacle?'

questions.question: True or False: Speaking truth only outwardly, not in one's heart, qualifies a person to dwell on God's holy hill according to Psalms 15:2.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 specifies speaking truth in the heart as a requirement, not merely outward speech.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:3, which of the following actions is forbidden?
questions.correctAnswer: Doing evil to a neighbour
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 states the righteous person does not do evil to their neighbour.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 15:4: 'He that honoureth them that fear the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 mentions the person who honours those that fear the LORD.

questions.question: What is the outcome for the person who does the things described in Psalms 15:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall never be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 concludes that the one who does these righteous things 'shall never be moved.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:4, what is the attitude of the righteous toward a vile person?
questions.correctAnswer: Contempt
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 states that in the eyes of the righteous, a vile person is contemned.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 teach us about integrity in daily work and speech?
options: Walk uprightly, work righteousness, and speak truth in your heart
Avoid work and focus on prayer only
questions.correctAnswer: Walk uprightly, work righteousness, and speak truth in your heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 emphasizes walking uprightly, working righteousness, and speaking truth in the heart as marks of integrity in daily life, which aligns with the biblical virtues of honesty and faithfulness in work and speech.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with gossip and speaks ill of others. What biblical truth from Psalms 15 would you share?
options: He that backbiteth not with his tongue nor doeth evil to his neighbour is righteous
It is acceptable to criticize others for their faults
Silence is the best policy when angry
Only speak about others when necessary
questions.correctAnswer: He that backbiteth not with his tongue nor doeth evil to his neighbour is righteous
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 highlights that a righteous person does not backbite or harm their neighbor, teaching the importance of loving speech and refraining from gossip or slander.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 15, what attitude should a believer have toward those who fear the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Honor them
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 instructs believers to honor those who fear the LORD, showing respect and reverence for fellow believers who walk in faith and obedience.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 address keeping promises even when it causes personal loss?
options: Swear to your own hurt and do not change
Avoid making promises to prevent loss
Break promises if it benefits you
Make vague promises to protect yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Swear to your own hurt and do not change
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 teaches that a faithful person keeps their word even when it causes personal harm, highlighting the biblical virtue of steadfastness and integrity.

questions.question: What does Psalms 15 say about financial dealings and justice?
options: Do not put out money to usury nor take reward against the innocent
Charge as much interest as possible
questions.correctAnswer: Do not put out money to usury nor take reward against the innocent
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 instructs believers to avoid exploiting others through usury or accepting bribes, emphasizing justice and honesty in stewardship and financial dealings.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to lie for personal gain. Based on Psalms 15, what counsel is appropriate?
options: Speak the truth in your heart and walk uprightly
Lie if it benefits you and no one finds out
questions.correctAnswer: Speak the truth in your heart and walk uprightly
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 encourages upright walking and truthful speech as foundational to righteous living, guiding believers to resist lying and uphold integrity.

questions.question: How does this passage teach us about humility and discernment regarding sinful people?
options: Contemn vile persons but honor those who fear the LORD
Ignore all people regardless of their conduct
Associate closely with sinners to change them
questions.correctAnswer: Contemn vile persons but honor those who fear the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 shows the balance of rejecting wickedness while honoring godly fear, teaching humility and wise discernment in relationships.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 15, a person who keeps their word even when it causes personal loss is considered righteous.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:4 highlights that swearing to your own hurt and not changing is a mark of righteousness, emphasizing faithfulness and integrity.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 15 permits taking advantage of neighbors by spreading harmful rumors.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 explicitly states that the righteous do not backbite or do evil to their neighbors, forbidding harmful speech and actions.

questions.question: A Christian wants to demonstrate godly generosity and stewardship. According to Psalms 15, which behavior should they avoid?
questions.correctAnswer: Putting out money to usury
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 teaches not to lend money with interest (usury), promoting fair and generous stewardship rather than exploitation.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 guide believers in maintaining peace and love with their neighbors?
options: Do not do evil to your neighbor nor take up a reproach against them
Speak only when spoken to by neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: Do not do evil to your neighbor nor take up a reproach against them
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 encourages not harming or accusing neighbors wrongly, promoting peace and loving relationships.

questions.question: What is the final promise given to those who live according to the principles in Psalms 15?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall never be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 concludes that those who practice righteousness and justice will have stability and security, symbolized by never being moved.

questions.question: A believer struggles with maintaining honesty at work. Which teaching from Psalms 15 would encourage them to persevere?
options: Work righteousness and speak truth in your heart
Avoid work to focus on prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Work righteousness and speak truth in your heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 encourages upright walking and truthful speech, affirming the importance of integrity even in challenging circumstances.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "LORD, who shall abide in thy _____? who shall dwell in thy holy hill?"
questions.correctAnswer: tabernacle
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:1 opens by asking who may dwell in the LORD's tabernacle, highlighting the theme of holiness and fellowship with God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 guide us in dealing with temptation to accept bribes or rewards unjustly?
options: Do not take reward against the innocent
questions.correctAnswer: Do not take reward against the innocent
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:5 teaches refusing bribes that harm the innocent, emphasizing justice and righteousness in dealings with others.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:2, which three qualities must a person possess to dwell in the LORD's tabernacle?
options: Walk uprightly, work righteousness, and speak truth in the heart
Give offerings, fast regularly, and pray fervently
Keep the Sabbath, honor parents, and avoid idolatry
Offer sacrifices, build altars, and observe festivals
questions.correctAnswer: Walk uprightly, work righteousness, and speak truth in the heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 explicitly states that he who 'walketh uprightly, and worketh righteousness, and speaketh the truth in his heart' shall abide in God's presence.

questions.question: Which action mentioned in Psalms 15:3 is prohibited in relation to one's neighbor?
options: Backbiting and doing evil to the neighbor
questions.correctAnswer: Backbiting and doing evil to the neighbor
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:3 forbids backbiting with the tongue and doing evil to one's neighbor, emphasizing interpersonal righteousness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 15:4 states, 'In whose eyes a vile person is _______; but he honoureth them that fear the LORD.'
questions.correctAnswer: contemned
questions.explanation: The verse clearly uses the word 'contemned' to describe how the upright person views the vile, showing moral discernment.

questions.question: The promise that 'He that doeth these things shall never be moved' in Psalms 15:5 can be seen as a foreshadowing of which New Testament theme?
options: The steadfastness of the righteous in Christ
The coming of the Holy Spirit
The establishment of the Kingdom of Heaven
questions.correctAnswer: The steadfastness of the righteous in Christ
questions.explanation: The stability of the righteous described in Psalms 15:5 parallels New Testament teachings on abiding in Christ and remaining unshaken.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 15 emphasizes both ethical behavior and truthful speech as necessary for dwelling with God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 highlight walking uprightly, working righteousness, and speaking truth, indicating both ethical and truthful speech are required.

questions.question: Which Old Testament law is echoed in Psalms 15:5's prohibition against taking reward against the innocent?
questions.correctAnswer: Exodus 23:8 forbidding bribes
questions.explanation: The prohibition against accepting bribes in Psalms 15:5 aligns with Exodus 23:8, which forbids taking bribes to pervert justice.

questions.question: In Psalms 15:4, the phrase 'He that sweareth to his own hurt, and changeth not' exemplifies what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism emphasizing faithfulness
questions.explanation: The structure pairs swearing at one's own hurt with steadfastness, a common Hebrew parallelism highlighting faithfulness.

questions.question: How does the concept of 'not putting out money to usury' in Psalms 15:5 relate to the cultural context of the ancient Near East?
options: It reflects prohibitions against exploitative lending practices common in Israelite law
It encourages economic prosperity through interest
It advocates for international trade agreements
It promotes charging high interest to foreigners only
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects prohibitions against exploitative lending practices common in Israelite law
questions.explanation: Ancient Israelite law, as reflected here, forbade charging interest to fellow Israelites to protect the poor from exploitation, a key social justice theme.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 15 aligns with the ethical teachings found in the Sermon on the Mount (Matthew 5-7)?
options: Integrity and righteousness in daily conduct
Temple sacrifices as a means of salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity and righteousness in daily conduct
questions.explanation: Psalms 15 emphasizes upright walking and righteousness, paralleling Jesus' teaching on internal purity and ethical living.

questions.question: True or False: The question in Psalms 15:1 serves as a literary device introducing criteria for entering God's holy place.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The opening question sets the tone and introduces the theme, functioning as a literary frame for the psalm's ethical requirements.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew word translated as 'abide' in Psalms 15:1 imply about the relationship between the righteous and God's presence?
options: To dwell permanently in intimate fellowship
To live outside the city gates
questions.correctAnswer: To dwell permanently in intimate fellowship
questions.explanation: The Hebrew verb suggests a stable, ongoing dwelling, indicating deep communion with God rather than temporary presence.

questions.question: Which New Testament character’s integrity is exemplified by the description in Psalms 15:4 of one who 'sweareth to his own hurt, and changeth not'?
options: Joseph, the earthly father of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph, the earthly father of Jesus
questions.explanation: Joseph showed steadfast commitment to righteousness and made difficult decisions without changing his resolve, fitting the psalm’s portrayal.

questions.question: Psalms 15 can be seen as a form of wisdom literature due to its emphasis on what central theme?
options: Moral conduct as prerequisite for communion with God
questions.correctAnswer: Moral conduct as prerequisite for communion with God
questions.explanation: The psalm outlines ethical behavior as essential for dwelling with God, a hallmark of wisdom literature’s practical spirituality.

questions.question: Which structural pattern best describes Psalms 15?
options: A series of conditions describing the righteous person
A prophetic oracle about the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: A series of conditions describing the righteous person
questions.explanation: The psalm lists character traits and behaviors that qualify one to dwell with God, forming a didactic series of conditions.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 relate to the concept of holiness in Leviticus?
options: Both emphasize moral purity and integrity as necessary for approaching God
Both focus exclusively on ritual cleanliness
Both command building altars on holy hills
Both prescribe animal sacrifices for sin
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize moral purity and integrity as necessary for approaching God
questions.explanation: While Leviticus includes ritual laws, it also stresses ethical holiness, which Psalms 15 echoes by focusing on righteous behavior for dwelling with God.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:1, what is the primary inquiry posed to the LORD?
options: Who shall abide in thy tabernacle and dwell on thy holy hill?
Who shall sing praises to the LORD forever?
Who shall lead the people with justice?
Who shall offer sacrifices with a pure heart?
questions.correctAnswer: Who shall abide in thy tabernacle and dwell on thy holy hill?
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:1 explicitly asks who is worthy to dwell in God's sacred presence, reflecting God's holiness and the sanctity of His dwelling place, which is consistent with God's desire for purity as seen in Exodus 25:8, Isaiah 57:15, John 14:2-3, and Revelation 21:3.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics does Psalms 15:2 list as necessary for one who may dwell with God?
options: Walk uprightly, work righteousness, and speak truth in the heart
Offer sacrifices and observe the law meticulously
Fast regularly and give alms to the poor
Pray continually and keep the Sabbath holy
questions.correctAnswer: Walk uprightly, work righteousness, and speak truth in the heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 15:2 emphasizes moral integrity and inward truthfulness, underlying that true worship is inseparable from righteous living, which aligns with Proverbs 10:9, Micah 6:8, Ephesians 4:25, and 1 John 3:18.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:3, which behavior disqualifies a person from dwelling with God?
options: Backbiting with the tongue and doing evil to one's neighbor
Ignoring the poor and neglecting the temple
Speaking in parables and withholding tithes
questions.correctAnswer: Backbiting with the tongue and doing evil to one's neighbor
questions.explanation: Verse 3 condemns slander and harm toward others, highlighting God's justice and love for neighbor, consistent with Leviticus 19:16, Matthew 22:39, James 4:11, and Romans 13:10.

questions.question: What does Psalms 15:4 say about the person’s view toward the 'vile' and those who fear the LORD?
options: He contemns the vile but honors those who fear the LORD
He befriends the vile and ignores the godly
He fears the vile and despises the humble
He judges all equally without distinction
questions.correctAnswer: He contemns the vile but honors those who fear the LORD
questions.explanation: This verse distinguishes between the morally corrupt and the reverent, demonstrating the believer's allegiance to God's holiness, consistent with Proverbs 3:7, Isaiah 66:2, Romans 12:9, and 1 Peter 3:8.

questions.question: According to Psalms 15:4, what is said about someone who swears to their own hurt?
options: He swears and does not change
He swears only in times of joy
questions.correctAnswer: He swears and does not change
questions.explanation: The verse highlights unwavering integrity even at personal loss, reflecting God's faithfulness and calling for human honesty as seen in Numbers 30:3, Matthew 5:37, James 5:12, and Hebrews 6:18.

questions.question: What financial conduct does Psalms 15:5 prohibit for those who wish to dwell with God?
options: Putting out money to usury and accepting bribes against the innocent
Giving alms to the poor and sacrificing tithes
Investing in the temple treasury and lending freely
Trading goods honestly and keeping accurate accounts
questions.correctAnswer: Putting out money to usury and accepting bribes against the innocent
questions.explanation: This verse forbids exploitation and corruption, emphasizing justice and fairness in economic dealings, consistent with Exodus 22:25, Leviticus 19:15, Deuteronomy 16:19, and Proverbs 28:6.

questions.question: Which statement best summarizes the promise given in Psalms 15:5 to those who live according to these commands?
options: They will inherit riches and honor
They will be exalted above kings
questions.correctAnswer: They shall never be moved
questions.explanation: The psalm promises stability and security to the righteous, reflecting God’s sustaining power as also taught in Psalm 1:3, Isaiah 54:10, Matthew 7:24-25, and 1 Corinthians 15:58.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 reflect the doctrine of imago Dei (image of God) in human moral behavior?
options: By portraying uprightness, truth, and justice as essential to dwelling with God
By emphasizing ritual sacrifice over ethical conduct
By focusing on external purity without regard to the heart
By asserting that only priests may approach God
questions.correctAnswer: By portraying uprightness, truth, and justice as essential to dwelling with God
questions.explanation: The psalm implies humans created in God's image must reflect His holiness through righteousness and truthfulness, consistent with Genesis 1:27, Micah 6:8, Ephesians 4:24, and Colossians 3:10.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implied in Psalms 15:5 about the righteous?
options: They shall never be moved, implying eternal security in God's presence
They will reign physically on earth for a thousand years
They will be exempt from all trials in this life
They will be immediately glorified without resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: They shall never be moved, implying eternal security in God's presence
questions.explanation: The promise of immovability points toward eternal stability with God, resonating with Daniel 12:3, Matthew 25:46, 1 Peter 1:5, and Revelation 21:7.

questions.question: How does the requirement to "speak the truth in his heart" (Psalms 15:2) address common objections about inner integrity and worship?
options: It teaches that worship must be sincere and not merely external
It allows for deceit if public worship is maintained
It prioritizes ritual over personal honesty
It permits hypocrisy as long as prayers are offered
questions.correctAnswer: It teaches that worship must be sincere and not merely external
questions.explanation: The verse underscores the necessity for internal truthfulness, countering any notion that external religious acts suffice without heartfelt integrity, as supported by Isaiah 29:13, Jeremiah 17:10, Matthew 15:8, and Hebrews 4:12.

questions.question: Which Christological theme is foreshadowed by the psalmist’s description of the righteous person who 'sweareth to his own hurt, and changeth not' (Psalms 15:4)?
options: The sinless obedience and unchanging faithfulness of Christ
The need for human perfection without divine help
The importance of ritual purity for salvation
The role of angels as mediators between God and man
questions.correctAnswer: The sinless obedience and unchanging faithfulness of Christ
questions.explanation: This steadfast integrity prefigures Christ’s perfect obedience and immutability, aligning with Hebrews 7:26, 1 Peter 2:22, John 14:6, and Revelation 1:8.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 teach about the nature of sin in relation to community life?
options: Sin disrupts relationships by backbiting, doing evil, and bearing false witness
Sin is primarily a private matter between God and the individual
Sin is only about ritual impurity and sacrifices
Sin is unavoidable and thus excused in community
questions.correctAnswer: Sin disrupts relationships by backbiting, doing evil, and bearing false witness
questions.explanation: The psalm highlights interpersonal sins that damage communal harmony, consistent with Leviticus 19:16, Proverbs 6:16-19, Matthew 5:21-22, and James 4:11.

questions.question: In Psalms 15:5, what is the significance of not 'taking reward against the innocent' in the light of biblical justice?
options: It emphasizes impartiality and fairness, condemning corruption
It permits bribery if it benefits the community
It focuses only on temple priests’ conduct
It allows favoritism toward the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes impartiality and fairness, condemning corruption
questions.explanation: This prohibition aligns with God’s justice requiring no partiality or bribery, as seen in Exodus 23:8, Deuteronomy 16:19, Proverbs 17:23, and Luke 11:43.

questions.question: What ecclesiological principle can be derived from the qualities listed in Psalms 15 for those who dwell with God?
options: The church community must be composed of morally upright, truthful, and just individuals
The church should focus on ceremonial observances alone
The church accepts all regardless of conduct
The church emphasizes wealth as a sign of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: The church community must be composed of morally upright, truthful, and just individuals
questions.explanation: The psalm stresses holiness and integrity as prerequisites to God's presence, a principle foundational to the church's identity, supported by Acts 2:42-47, 1 Timothy 3:2-7, Ephesians 4:25, and Hebrews 12:14.

questions.question: How does Psalms 15 contribute to apologetics against the objection that God’s presence is arbitrary or unconditional?
options: It shows God’s presence is reserved for those who live righteously and with integrity
It teaches that anyone can dwell with God regardless of conduct
It suggests God’s presence is only for priests and kings
It claims that ritual alone grants access to God
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God’s presence is reserved for those who live righteously and with integrity
questions.explanation: The psalm clarifies that God’s fellowship is not arbitrary but requires ethical and moral purity, parallel to Isaiah 6:3-7, Ezekiel 36:25-27, John 14:15, and 1 John 3:7.
